Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Intensive mentored Research Experiences for Undergraduates in psychology and neuroscience at an urban public college

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is supported under the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program, which is an NSF-wide program although each Directorate administers its own REU Site competition. This program supports active research participation by undergraduate students in an effort to introduce them to scientific research so as to encourage their continued engagement in the nation's scientific research and development enterprise. REU projects involve students in meaningful ways in ongoing research programs or in research projects designed especially for the purpose. The REU program is a major contributor to the NSF's goal of developing a diverse, internationally competitive, and globally-engaged science and engineering workforce. The Social, Behavioral and Economic (SBE) sciences Directorate awarded this REU Site grant to the Brooklyn College (BC) in the City University of New York (CUNY); it is a renewal of an ongoing REU Site at this location. The objective of the project is to immerse diverse students in innovative research in psychology and neuroscience. The REU Program aims to advance scientific discovery for the scientific and broader communities while promoting mentoring, learning, and professional development by: (1) increasing participation of students from underrepresented groups (primarily women, racial minorities, first-generation college students) in neuroscience research; (2) guiding students through the scientific process, from generation of research questions to communication of results; (3) immersing students in didactics that highlight the relevance and applied value of their laboratory work; (4) enhancing students' competitiveness for graduate school and professional positions; and (5) boosting the research competence of local high school teachers with downstream positive learning effects for their students. This REU Program also enables faculty members to supervise talented individuals who might otherwise miss out on mentored laboratory and professional development experiences, and contributes to the training and advancement of the next generation of psychologists and neuroscientists.

The central (scientific) component of this REU Program is a semester-long laboratory immersion, under the supervision of Psychology Department faculty mentors, which results in a completed research project. REU students are exposed to a variety of behavioral, neuroscientific, and computational methods to execute their projects. High quality research and the integration of psychological theory with the design, execution, and interpretation of neuroscientific data are emphasized. Ten students are selected annually for mentored research projects, especially undergraduates at ethnic-minority serving, public two-year and four-year institutions in the New York metropolitan area. Students attend weekly didactics: a neuroscience seminar that dually focuses on neuroscience principles/research methods and professional issues; a journal club that familiarizes students with scientific literature in modern neuroscience through learning to select, read, and critically analyze original research papers; and a statistical methods seminar that emphasizes data analysis, statistical reasoning, and presenting research findings in academic contexts. Students also undergo intensive neuroethics training. As a capstone experience, students present a poster at the BC Science Research Day, where they compete for awards based on the quality of their work and ability to communicate their findings. In addition, the project has a RET (Research Experiences for Teachers) component, which provides local high school teachers with coursework in research methods, mentored laboratory experience, and professional development opportunities to enhance their neuroscience literacy and raise the level of science education in local high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2016-2018, the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program at Brooklyn College (BC) has immersed diverse students in innovative research on psychology and neuroscience along with professional development experiences. We have engaged students in the excitement of scientific discovery while providing critical preparation for graduate study and future professional endeavors. Ten students were selected annually, especially undergraduates at ethnic-minority serving, public, two- and four-year institutions in the NYC metropolitan area. In addition, the project had a RET (Research Experiences for Teachers) component, which provided local middle and high school teachers with coursework in research methods, mentored laboratory experience, and professional development opportunities to enhance their research competencies and raise the level of science education in local middle schools and high schools. Table 1 presents demographic characteristics of REU students aggregated over three years, and Figure 1 shows our 2018 cohort and graduate instructors. Table 2 presents the demographic and professional characteristics of RET participants.

The central component of the BC REU program was a semester-long laboratory immersion, under the supervision of Psychology, Biology, and Chemistry Department faculty mentors, which resulted in a completed research project. We emphasized the generation of high-quality research and integration of psychological and neuroscientific theory with the design, execution, and interpretation of data. We also encouraged students to present and publish their results. All 30 REU students presented first-authored posters at the annual BC Science Day, where they competed for College-wide, interdepartmental awards based on work quality and ability to communicate findings. Figure 2 displays examples of these presentations. Among hundreds of conference presenters, several REU students received awards (including first place in the undergraduate division in 2016) and additional honors and fellowships within CUNY and nationally. Also, REU student-related projects were accepted for presentation at professional conferences and for publication as peer-reviewed manuscripts. 

REU students attended weekly seminars complementing their laboratory work and highlighting its relevance and applied value. These didactics were instructed by doctoral students and included: (1) a seminar that dually focused on psychology and neuroscience principles/research methods and professional issues/career development; (2) a journal club that familiarized students with scientific literature through learning to select, read, critically analyze, and present summaries of original research papers; and (3) a statistical methods seminar that emphasized data analysis, statistical reasoning, and presentation of research findings in academic contexts. Given the importance of adhering to ethical norms in research, our students also underwent scientific ethics training.

An important goal of the REU program was to increase participation of students from underrepresented groups (e.g., women, racial minorities, first-generation college students) in the fields of psychology and neuroscience, beyond the REU program. Of our 30 students, 5 have enrolled in competitive doctoral programs in psychology, 7 are applying for or awaiting doctoral admissions decisions, 5 are enrolled in master degree programs (in disciplines such as biotechnology, experimental psychology, and neuroscience), and an additional 6 are still undergraduates or recent college graduates preparing for graduate school. 

We also recruited six teachers from middle and high schools in NYC. A highlight of the RET program was that teachers completed 100 hours of research experience and developed hands-on lesson plans related to their research experiences. Based on teacher feedback, the RET program increased teachers' knowledge about contemporary research and its practical applications. One RET participant described the program as shaping her teaching by allowing her to be more aware of how her students were learning. Another participant found that her students were interested in learning about her research experience and were enthusiastic about examining societal issues from a scientific lens. We hope that the RET program will serve as a critical pathway toward student growth and engagement in psychology, biology, and other STEM fields.1-2

We are engaged in ongoing research related to important REU/RET outcomes.3-7 One study, recently presented at the 2018 American Psychological Association convention, found that at the end of the program REU students overwhelmingly reported benefitting from one-on-one time spent with mentors. Those who felt comfortable with their mentors were more likely to approach mentors when struggling with a research, interpersonal, or unexpected issue in the lab.5 Another study, soon to be submitted for peer-review, found that over the course of the REU program, students improved in statistical reasoning and analytic skills.8

To disseminate our activities, we maintain a website that provides information about the program and its requirements, the application process, laboratory opportunities, and program contacts. Website: http://www.brooklyn.cuny.edu/web/academics/schools/naturalsciences/undergraduate/psychology/research/reu.php

We also maintain a Tumblr blog so that current and former REU/RET participants can share thoughts and experiences related to scientific publications, news, culture, and events. This blog features program-related research and other professional accomplishments. Blog: http://bcreu.tumblr.com

In sum, over the past three years we implemented an innovative REU/RET program, which we hope will serve as a model for research training at and beyond our institution.
